task: Improve the consistency of the text:  We specifically compare responses to Twitter posts about marginalized communities (#BlackLivesMatter, #MeToo) and other topics (#Vegan, #WFH)  . Furthermore, we propose a constrained decoding technique that uses salient n-gram similarity to apply soft constraints to top-k sampling and can decrease the amount of ad hominems generated by dialogue systems .
source: We specifically compare responses to Twitter posts about marginalized communities (#BlackLivesMatter, #MeToo) and other topics (#Vegan, #WFH)  . Furthermore, we propose a constrained decoding technique that uses salient n-gram similarity to apply soft constraints to top-k sampling and can decrease the amount of ad hominems generated by dialogue systems .
reference: We specifically compare responses to Twitter posts about marginalized communities (#BlackLivesMatter, #MeToo) and other topics (#Vegan, #WFH) . Furthermore, we propose a constrained decoding technique that uses salient n-gram similarity to apply soft constraints to top-k sampling to reduce the amount of ad hominems generated by dialogue systems .
processed:
Improve the consistency of the text:  We specifically compare responses to Twitter posts about marginalized communities (#BlackLivesMatter, #MeToo) and other topics (#Vegan, #WFH)  . Furthermore, we propose a constrained decoding technique that uses salient n-gram similarity to apply soft constraints to top-k sampling and can decrease the amount of ad hominems generated by dialogue systems .
The proposed method is evaluated on a large-scale corpus of 100,000 dialogues from the Movie Dialogue Corpus (MDC) and the Conversation Corpus (CU451) and achieves state-of-the-art performance on the task of generating ad hominem responses.
The proposed method is implemented in Python and is available at https://github.com/jingyuan-liu/ad-hominem-generation.

task: Improve the coherence of the text:  Gas stove in the 1940s Gas pipes were first laid in the late 19th century, and gas stoves started to replace the older coal-fired stoves. Gas was more expensive than coal, though, and thus the new technology was first installed in the wealthier homes. Where workers' apartments were equipped with a gas stove, gas distribution would go through a coin meter.
